participants.participant: Caroline Millot, Head of Investor Relations
Jean Régis Carof, Director of Shareholder and Market Authority Relations
Christian Mulliez, Executive Vice-President Administration and Finance

plist.p: Good morning, Caroline. Is everyone back from coffee? Not quite. Jean Régis is in charge. We're going to manage. Don't move Jean Régis. We are going to start off. It is 08:30. We're going to start. Good morning, everyone. We're very happy to welcome you to this meeting for the presentation of our First-Half Results for 2008. We are going to do it as we do every year.

First of all, I'll ask Christian Mulliez to give you a full and detailed presentation of our results for the first half after which I will be commenting personally, as I always do, these results and what should be kept in mind. And I will indicate our outlook for the year 2008 and we will be at your disposal with Christian to answer your questions as best as we can.
As usual, we are going to ask Jean Régis to give us a few housekeeping instructions.

Good morning, ladies. Good morning, gentlemen. Before we begin the meeting, I would like to give you a few details as to the practical arrangements for the meeting. You will have found at the entrance of the room headsets. For simultaneous interpretation, you will have English on channel two. So we suggest you switch to that channel if you wish now. A telecommunications room with Internet access is available for you, the hostesses may lead you to the room and we would like you to please switch off your cell phones. At the entrance, you were handed the two booklets with the tables in two languages, which Mr. Mulliez and Agon will be commenting. A copy of the accounts will be – press release will be given to you at the end of the meeting.

The meeting will be broadcast on your dedicated website, loreal-finance.com, and all the presentations and the webcast of the meeting will be available and your presentations and webcast on that same site after 4:00 PM this afternoon. Following this meeting, a light snack will be served at the Poiet bar opposite this room. Thank you for your attention. Thank you, Jean Régis. It's going to be a light snack, because times are tough.
So Christian, you're going to start off with the results.

Good morning, ladies and gentlemen. The presentation of the L'Oréal results for the first half of 2008 will start with a quick reminder of the elements included in the half-yearly sales communicated to you on the 17th of July. We will continue with the presentation of the P&L, the flows, and the balance sheet.

The sales for the first half of 2008 reached €8.646 billion, up at constant exchange rate by 7.1%. External growth impact was positive by 1.8%, corresponding to the acquisitions in the United States in the area of hair salons, of distributors of professional products, Beauty Alliance, Maly's West, and Columbia Beauty Systems (sic) [Columbia Beauty Supply], and of the PureOlogy brand.
In Turkey, there was the acquisition of the Canan Company, and in Dermatology, the purchase of the CollaGenex Company in the United States by our joint venture, Galderma.

In order to help you in your projections for 2008, we can indicate that the external growth impact for the whole year of 2008, including the acquisition of Yves Saint Laurent Beauté, consolidated since the first of July 2008, and excluding any new acquisition should be in the order of plus 3.5%.

As regards the exchange rate impact, there was a negative impact of minus 5.5% on the 30th of June. Here again, for the entire year 2008, by extrapolating the current exchange rates for the rest of the year, we work on the basis of an exchange rate between the euro and the dollar of 1.49. This negative impact should reach a bit less than 5%.

Exchange rate, on this table, we are communicating, in a decreasing order, the weight in our sales of currencies other than the euro. We see, of course, the prevailing impact of the dollar in the negative exchange rate impact, which is very significant in the first half of 2008. We should also note that since 2007, there are four currencies of what we call the BRICM countries that are included among the eight major currencies of the L'Oréal Group, the Russian Ruble, the Chinese Yuan, the Brazilian Real, and Mexican Peso.

Another useful element, the weight of the Eurozone accounted for 37.2% of our consolidated sales in the first half of 2008, which is stable compared to the first half of 2007. 2008, unfortunately, is a record year when it comes to negative exchange rate impact and this is the case for the last 20 years, excepting 2003, and this is the reason why you have seen this in the press release and you would see it in the presentation. We will insist this year on presenting these different businesses and operations at constant exchange rates.

Talking now about the consolidated profit and loss account, the sales was established at 8.646 billion, up 70 – up 7.1% at constant exchange rate, and 1.6% on a reported basis. Gross margin reached 6.141 billion, 71% of the sales. The gross margin is stable as the percentage of the sales compared to 2007 and slightly down compared to the first half of 2007.

There are several factors that impact the evolution of the gross margin from half-year to half-year that need to be identified to analyze the underlying performance of the Group, and that's what we are going to do with the following table.

As we keep reminding you since the presentation of the annual results in 2006, the development of the gross margin every year is impacted by the changes in exchange rates. We thus calculated that in a constant manner, there are about three quarters of all exchange gains and losses reflected in the P&L. Roughly three-quarters of these exchange gains and losses are attributable to the gross margin, to be precise 80% in the first half of 2008.

By restating these items, by reallocating to the gross margin, its share of exchange gains as included in the P&L, it appears that its evolution or development in the first half of 2008 – and the first half of 2008 is established as minus 20 basis points. It is the first factor that you can see reflected in this table.

The second factor is the outcome of the integration of the acquisitions in the United States of distributors of professional products, the operating structure of which is very different from that of the rest of the Group. We consider that the negative impact due to the integration of these distributors on our gross margin is about 10 basis points for the first half, by integrating all of the other elements including the impact of stocks step-ups during the acquisition. By adding these two factors, in other words, the allocation of exchange gains, and excluding the integration of distributors of professional products, the gross margin would have been only very slightly down, to the order of about 10 basis points of our sales.

The third factor, which is not exchange gains and losses but the level of hedging. Let's take the dollar situation, for example. This impact is €0.11 because the average hedging levels were taken in 2008 at 1.36, whereas the hedging level in 2007 was 1.25. The market was different then. So 1.36 now against 1.25 in 2007, €0.11, that's the impact. We consider that for all the currencies, the differences in the levels of hedging cost us a loss of gross margin to the tune of 30 basis points.

The third factor – this third adverse factor was compensated by the improvement of the sales cost, resulting from the efforts we made in terms of productivity, and this was combined to the value effect on the sales. With these decisions on the gross margin, we can now continue with the examination of the other items on the P&L.

The R&D costs, it's at €272 million, are stable in absolute value, slightly down as a percentage of the sales compared to the first half of 2007. Advertising and promotional costs was very variable over one half year. They come out at 2.570 billion, slightly down compared to the sales at 29% – 29.7% against 30% in 2007 and 30.5% in the first half of 2007.

This decrease is even lower if we take into account the negative growth impact of the integration of distributors of professional products in the United States. It would then be only 30 basis points. It is important to also specify that including here in this item, there are productivity efforts that are being made, but when it comes to immediate buying, because what we do is centralize and outsource, and we also continue with these productivity improvement efforts for the advertising on the point of sales.

A bit lower down, SG&A reached €1.829 billion and represent 21.2% of the sales, stable compared to 2007 and up 30 basis points compared to the first half of 2007. This level would be stable by excluding from half-year-to-half-year once again the impact of the integration of distributors of American products. Again, they're really very happy because of their operating profit and the increase of the IFRS charge on discretion.

Let me remind you that 2008 is the last year since 2004 where we can see an increase in this expanding on this IFRS charge because it is being accounted for progressively over five years since 2004. We are keeping here – we are sticking here to the IFRS rules. This impact to which almost 10 basis points will disappear as of 2009 which is good news.

Exchange gains now. We've already mentioned them. We had to look at them when we looked at the gross margin as established at plus €28.1 million. This is in fact may have come as the difference between 11 million as the time value and a gain of 39 million as intrinsic value, and over 2008 at the current exchange rates, this is the assumption, the exchange gain should be established at 65 to €70 million in total.
The profit and loss account at €1.498 billion is up by 8.5% at constant exchange rates and 3.9% on a reported basis. It reached 17.3% of the sales, up 40 basis points compared to the first-half 2007.

Now the history of half years, once again, we would like to insist on the fact that there is a great deal of variability in half-yearly profitability levels at the L'Oréal Company and we would like to remind you here of the history over the last few years. You can see first of all in this table that a first half is rarely indicative of what the whole year will be. We see on this table since 2008, one, that there is a very strong increase in the profitability levels of L'Oréal, both on a half-yearly basis on the first line and on a full-year basis on the last line of this table at 17.3% of the sales, this first half-year is a record half-year in terms of the half-yearly profitability of the L'Oréal Group. Let's talk now about the different branches and divisions.
Once again, the figures cannot be extrapolated as you predict the profitability of the different divisions for the whole year.

Cosmetic division, first of all, the profitability increased by 20 – from 20.6% of the sales in the first half of 2007 to 21.1% of the sales in the first half of 2008. Professional Products division, 21.1% compared to 21.3% in the first half of 2007. Here again, there is a negative external growth impact of the integration of American distributors because if we were to exclude that, then profitability would have increased from 22.3% in the first half of 2007 to 22.6% in the first half of 2008.

Consumer Products division, 21.4%, at historically high level to be compared to 20.6% in the first half of 2007. The Luxury Products division, profitability is always higher in the second half for this division. This division reached 19.6% to be compared to 19.1% in the first half of 2007. Conversely, in the Active Cosmetics division, we have 24.8% of the sales, which is at very high level. Its profitability decreased slightly compared to the first half of 2007 because now the figure is 24.3%, here again the seasonality effect is very strong.

Few words about The Body Shop that remained practically stable at a level close to zero. You now know the very strong seasonality of this business and its profitability. All of its profitability in fact is achieved during the second half of the year.

Last point the dermatology branch, Galderma, profitability increased in the first half of 2008, profitability will increase in the course of the second half, because of very strong seasonality in this business, in particular, the acme franchise.

Comparability to P&L, from the P&L to the net income excluding non-recurring items, you know that this is in fact the basis for the calculation of our earning per share. Cost of the financial debt is down at €66.7 million and this is despite the increase in the interest rate and the continuation of the share buyback scheme. This positive effect is the consequent of the divestment of €1.5 billion of Sanofi shares in November 2007. For the entire year, we can anticipate, all things being equal, a financial cost to the tune of €180 million. This cost includes, of course, the interest paid on the loan for the acquisition of Yves Saint Laurent and this is not something that impacted the first year results.

The Sanofi-Aventis dividend remained practically stable at €245 million. Sanofi increased its dividend significantly. This stability is the result of the divestment of Sanofi shares that we completed in November 2007.

Pre-tax profit grew by 7.6% at constant exchange rates and 3.7% on reported basis. Total taxes reached to €414 million. The tax rate decreased from 26.7% in the first half of 2007 to 24.7% in the first half of 2008. This is the outcome both of the lower taxation levels in a number of countries Spain, Italy, Germany, Canada, and Great Britain. Secondly, a decrease in the research tax credit in France and is also the result of the favorable outcome of some tax disputes.

You know that the tax rate for the first half is hardly relevant to the annual tax rate because it includes a mix effect so that is advocated to the dividend paid by Sanofi, which are completely cashed in during the first half on the one hand, and secondly they are taxed at a level of about 2%.

In order to help you in your projections for the entire year, we can indicate that for 2008 we can expect a tax rate to the tune of 28% down compared to the 29.5% tax rate that we had in 2007. In total, after minority interests the net income excluding non-recurring elements reached €1,256 million, up 10.1% at constant exchange rate and 6.4% on a reported basis.

By integrating the positive impact of sale buybacks of plus 2.1%, the NEPS reached €2.11 per share and this is a two-digit growth of 12.3% at a constant exchange rate, and plus 8.5% on a reported basis. For the entire year 2008, we can consider today that the accretive impact of share buybacks should be close to 2.5%.

Moving on to the cash flow situation. Cash flow reached €1,534 million, up 5.4% which is consistent with the growth of our income on a reported basis. The – we always have this question, so let me answer the question straight away.

The depreciation and provisions line at €243 million is stable compared to the first half of 2007. This situation is the result of a slight increase in the depreciation line of €308 million in the first half of 2007 to €319 million in the first half of 2008. And on the other hand, there is an increase in the provisions of €58 million to €76 million. And this is the result of the policy to progressively fund a pension scheme commitment.

Working capital requirement as of the year – the end of June, the working capital requirement is much higher than what will be, it's the increase over the entire year. It has increased this year compared to 2007, €630 million against €453 million. It's not due to the inventories, trade debtors and supplies line, but to other current assets and liabilities, for example, the payment of partial tax payments, financial cost on the acquisition of Yves Saint Laurent, different discounts with anticipated payments because there will be a outsourcing of this type of purchases. Also we can see on this table, regarding inventories and trade debtors a very slight improvement in the percentage of the sales.

On the right hand side you can see that inventories established 9% of sales, compared to, if you look at the left hand side – compared to 9.4% on the 30th of June 2007, with the same global consolidation and trade debtors themselves account for 17.4% of the sales compared to 18.2% on the 30th of June 2007. Ending now with the flows over the entire yea, as I was saying the working capital requirement should increase much less than in the first half, as it's not something that can be accessed very precisely, but it should be to the tune of about €100 million.

Investments at €339 million established a 2.9% of our sales down compared to first half of 2007 for the whole year, this should be close to the percentage of the sales to the 2007 level, a bit lower maybe at 4.5%. After payment of dividends for €829 million entirely done in the first half after the acquisitions to the tune of €1,298 million including the acquisition of Yves Saint Laurent Beauté, share buyback for €553 million the residual flow is established at minus €2,108 million.

Three more tables before we finish. First of all, let's take stock of the acquisition of Yves Saint Laurent Beauté, which was completed on the 30th of June 2008. It has no consequence or no impact on the P&L for the first half of 2008. The balance sheet is impacted as follows; we're currently waiting on the final allocation to the balance sheet and this will be final on 31st of December 2008. So we have a net acquired situation of €64.4 million, in the assets €79 million for the inventories of €97 million for the trade debtors, a paid price of 1,107 million, and that's part of the additional debt and goodwill of €1.043 billion.

You will see this in your papers. These are absolute values, they are not restated, cannot be compared at all. And I would also like to remind you and this is an important point that we indicated that this acquisition should have a slightly dilutive effect on our 2008 P&L to the tune of about 1% bit more – slightly more or less than 1%, coming for half from the non-cash effect and the stock step-up impact.

The balance sheet now; structure of the balance sheet is robust. Share capital represents about 50% of all assets, the lower level compared to the 31st of December 2007 is because of the lower share value of Sanofi, but also the combined effect of the payment of dividend, which is done as one-off at L'Oréal, the share buybacks, and the negative conversion effect, and the net situation of the subsidiaries.

And this is due also to a significant exchange rate impact. And the last table is about the debt. Net debt is established at €4.520 billion on 30th of June 2008 compared to pretty much the same amount, €4,462 million on the 30th of June 2007, on the 31st of December 2008 should slightly higher than €3.700 billion, all things being equal. Thank you very much for you attention.

Thank you very much, Christian. I would now also like share with you my vision of our results for this first half. These results are according to me very positive and encouraging, given the fact that they were obtained in a monetary and economic context, which as you know was extremely difficult and adverse.

I would like to seize this opportunity to highlight the elements, which, I believe, are particularly important to note concerning our activity and our performance and finally I will give you an outlook for the year 2008, which as you know, and as Christian indicated at L'Oréal, a half year is not necessarily representive of the full year.

To begin with and as with the case in previous years a focus on the cosmetics markets for the first half of 2008. The first element to note in a very troubled economic context during the first half, the cosmetics markets on the whole have registered very well. According to our estimates, which must be used with some caution because they are still approximate, the growth of the global cosmetics market should be at plus 4% for the first six months of the year, i.e. a size slowing down compared with the plus 5% of last year.

The distribution of this growth, however, is different from what it was in 2007. The rest of the world region which I'd like to remind you is now the number one global cosmetic market with 30% of global markets concerned – kept a high pace at plus 9.4% compared with 10% in 2007, so practically no slowing down in that region. This region represents close to 35% of the global market. In North America 20%, and this region represents three quarters of the growth of the global market. As you may see on this table the dynamics of the market was very strong on all continents.

In Asia, we are speeded up. In Latin America and in Eastern Europe, where growth remained at plus 10 – at above 10%. All this indications lead us to believe that this dynamic trend should continue at a very strong level during the second half.

In Japan, the market is again flat and the share of the Japanese market continues to shrink overall globally. In Western Europe, in total, the markets resisted rather well with a growth, which remained at plus 2.5%.

The distribution of this growth around the countries has indeed changed, but the global rhythm hasn't dropped much. Spain, Great Britain, France and Italy have slowed down, but Germany and the Northern European countries have accelerated or maintained a high growth rate.

The market, which significantly slowed down and this was – this could be expected was of course the North American market where growth was down from 2.9% last year to 0.7% for this first half. It is quite a slowing down, but on the opposite the market remained positive in an economic environment, which was, particularly, adverse to consumption, which is rather good news. The other good news is that, generally speaking, we did not see during this first half a market trend for trading down on the part of consumers on the contrary whether it's in skincare or makeup or hair care, the trend is more towards trading up and this is the case in all of the circuits.

And on the other hand, there has not been a mass transfer towards private labels, whose share in cosmetics as you know is the lowest in all the categories in consumer products, even though it has been slightly increasing in Europe. In summary, cosmetics market resisted very well during the first half growth wise and value wise, and we believe that this good resistance should continue.

Then to the positive effects of innovation, which is important in our trade and which constantly renews the interest on the part of consumers and geographically thanks to the appetite for consumption of the new middle classes in emerging countries, which stimulates the global market.

As regards the growth of our sales during this first half, like-for-like, it was at 5.3% – 5.1% excluding Galderma, clearly above the estimated growth of the market. Also if you think in terms of constant exchange rate to estimate the real growth of the penetration of the L'Oréal Group on the global cosmetics market, growth was plus 6.8% and reflects a significant increase of the share of the global market for the Group which increased from 15.4% at the end of 2007 to 15.7% at the end of June 2008 and which should finish the year clearly above 16% taking into consideration the consolidation of Yves Saint Laurent Beauté.

Coming back to our growth like-for-like during the first half was achieved in a very differentiated way depending on the geographic results. For the rest of the world, which is the number one global market, it continued at a very high pace, 15.7%. In Asia excluding Japan growth reached a four-year record high with 23.5%, driven by China at plus 32% and also with several neighboring countries, which are close to this rhythm such as Hong Kong, Taiwan, Indonesia, Philippines, and even Korea, which is backed on a strong growth path at plus 20%.

Our Group is probably the one, which process the most. The fact is on this very strategic market for the future. In Japan, business achieved a 4% growth, which is a very honorable performance on a market, which is fast and more competitive than ever.

In Eastern Europe another very strategic region, which is catching up with the Western Europe, standards of living, our growth continued at a very high pace at plus 25.9%. Our growth was also very strong in Russia, but also in Ukraine, Poland, and practically all of the other countries in the region.

Our performance, however, was more contrasted in Latin America with a nice growth in Chile, Argentina, Venezuela, but on the contrary, with two major countries this year indicates during this first half, Brazil and Mexico, which saw no growth.

The good news is that this pause in growth is temporary and these two countries will be back on a growth pattern during the second half and will be again contributing positively to our growth in the country and the region, as they should.

And in India, there was also a slowdown, which would not be a lasting trend and other countries such as Dubai or South Africa also saw nice growth. In total our growth rhythm remains very strong above plus 15% for the rest of the world and the acceleration of certain countries have been compensated for this temporary slowing down of others.

We are very confident in our ability to maintain this growth pace during the second half, especially since some of the countries, which were lagging during the first half, should again be contributing positively.

In Western Europe, our growth in sales during the first half was at plus 1.3%. The indications we have from our panel leaders to believe that our sales was rather higher during this period. So that's a rhythm, which is close or identical to the market.
In consumer products, we have been able to achieve market shares to gain market shares and the growth was higher than that rhythm with very high scores in skincare and makeup.

In luxury products and professional products, the growth of our sales Group was also higher or equal to the market, which is not the case in active cosmetics were due to an insufficiently strong launch plan and due to the impact of seasonal products, the division did not grow.

The dynamics of our business on the whole continued to be good in sales Group, in Europe, during the first half, but our order income did not reach the same level, due to a launch plan and store availability, which retrospectively appear to have been too light, and due to tight inventory management by distributors.

Given our very busy upcoming launch plan, especially during the fourth quarter, we hope to be able to increase our sales Group, and our order income between now and at the end of the year. Our launch plan is very busy and very strong for the end of the year in Europe as elsewhere around the world to give you a few examples, in the Consumer Products division for L'Oréal Paris Excel10 and volume Collagen, a great mascara innovation and Elvive Re-Nutrition franchised from L'Oréal Paris.

In the Luxury Products division, it will be a great year for end of the year for Lancôme with the launch of a great new fragrance, Magnifique, which is being launched in Paris and in Europe. A great new lipstick, Le Rouge Absolu, a great innovation in mascara, the first electric mascara oscillation, and a great skin care product launch, Rénergie Microlift Night.

From Armani, the launch of Emporio Armani Diamonds for Men, from Ralph Lauren, there had been no launch for three years in women's fragrances, and there is a very great launch for women, Notorious, which seems to be off to a great start. From Diesel Attacherelle, Fuel for Life unlimited and Amor Amor Tentation. And of course from Yves Saint Laurent, Beauté, which has joined the Luxury division on the 1st of July. See these launches are not due to L'Oréal, but there will be a new lipstick, Volupté, from Yves Saint Laurent and the new fragrance B from Boucheron.

In the Professional Products division, many new initiatives, a new coloring paste, Platinium and the Nature series, and Kéraskin Esthetics. And finally, in the Active Cosmetics division, a new anti-line product, LiftActiv, a new product, energy from La Roche-Posay, Kerium anti-hair loss, and a powerful anti-age care product, Phloretin Serum from SkinCeuticals. So in total the share of launches in our sales should increase considerably during the second half compared with the first.

In North America, the market was the hardest hit by the economic recession. Our growth in the first half was of course disappointing at minus 0.5%. Consumer products, our sell-throughs were pretty much on par with market, very slightly positive.

Our positions are pretty much – in keeping the market, our positions remain very strong in hair coloring, makeup and we even saw an improvement in skincare with a confirmation of the success of the new Garnier Nutritionist line, which has gained a 7% market share in the United States, which is a considerably good result.

Luxury products in the United States, our brand suffered lack of initiatives on the first half of 2008, and that's why we have a very ambitious plan for the rest of the year. We fell behind the market; a very proactive launch plan will help us fight back. We've already heard the first feedback after the launching Notorious by Ralph Lauren and Armani Diamonds for Men and the feedback is extremely positive.

Professional products, we suffered first time because of our leading position of the shrinking of the market in the hair salon, but that will also mean that we will take full benefit of the upturn of the market when it happens and it will.

The Body Shop brand in the first half recorded good growth in retail sales of plus 6.1% and sales grew by 7.4% even though like-for-like sales slowed down at 0.9%. The business is currently implementing across all of its point of sales worldwide. Its new image and the new positioning of the brand that refocuses on its central value, natural and ethical values. And Galderma, as you saw, saw an increase in its growth rate on its sales of plus 17.5%. In total as you have gathered our growth for this first half slightly lower than our target of plus 6% outperformed the market nevertheless and has helped us to secure our worldwide positions and even develop them in a very strong way for in these strategic, new strategic markets which are Asia and Eastern Europe.

As already said in the press release because of our active launch scheme for the end of the year, all our teams are working hard towards a growth figure that would be higher than in the first half. This growth because of the launch timing should be a lot stronger of the fourth quarter than over the third quarter of 2008.

Christian Mulliez's presentation was very clear, in terms of the presentation of the operating profit. I wouldn't want to repeat what you already said. I'd like just to highlight a few points that are significant. First of all, generally speaking, because of the massive exchange rate impact we're suffering this year, which considerably distorts the reading of the operating results, and because of their complete instructions and volatile nature, we decided to present to you our results excluding the currency rate fluctuation which is more representative of the actual profit made by our operations, and this is how we have look at our income from operations for the first half of 2008.
We have an extremely adverse and challenging economic context, nevertheless we are faring very well in this context. And I would like to comment a few items.

First of all, gross margin, Christian has already explained, ones we re-stage the exchange gains and losses and the impact of the integration of American entities and distributors, the gross margin only dropped by 10 basis points. There would have been an improvement of 20 basis points if the hedging in 2008 had been taken at the same level of 2007. This improvement may seem to be fairly modest, but in fact it's considerable if we look at the exceptional pressure of the increases of cost that we suffered in the first half in terms of the raw material, the packaging items and energy. This is also obtained in all areas because of a number of initiatives. First of all, a maximum level of competition of all our worldwide purchases in four sourcing centers. A total review of our sourcing policy for the raw materials that has been to diversify our sourcing policy, to source our raw materials where we produce and to streamline our raw material catalogue.

Also another purpose was the total re-engineering of our purchasing processes for packaging items. Considerable progress was made in terms of increased quantities in such purchases, globalization of supplier contracts and a reduction in prices because of lighter weight packaging items.

Also we want a global deployment of the second phase of our project to renegotiate and reduce cost for all of our indirect purchases and want to continue our efforts to improve productive in all of our factories and the supply chain and this productivity will increase again significantly throughout the year. So a lot of progress will be made that will improve the gross margin, even in an extremely adverse and challenging economic and monetary context. We are firmly convinced that we have to continue making progress in this direction and there will be further areas for improvement and of course the results will be seen in next half of 2008.

Second point A&Ps, as you can see on this table, like-for-like excluding the integration of American distributors, which is the least we can do to analyze what we've done with our objectives, we can see that the A&Ps established 30.1% of our sales, which is very close to our current level to our normal level, identical to that of the first half of 2006 or the second half of 2007 and slightly higher than the first half of 2007. So it would seem that our sales field is stable.

In fact, if we look at – in terms of the resources deployed, the A&Ps are actually increasing, because as I indicated several times, we are in a period of high productivity gains in the promotional and advertising investment. All our media buying are centralized in buying centers, the latest movement or the latest trend within firms that we outsourced at the beginning of this year are media buying and has led to good streamlining optimization.

We've been deploying over the last three years across all divisions and across all continents, projects to optimize our purchases and to reduce our costs in terms of merchandising promotion and point of sales advertising, like we do in the industrial area and this is a grateful savings every year. All of this means that with the same level of investment, our A&P costs are in fact increasing and we're doing this because we want a worldwide expansion of our brands and products and this dynamic or this trend should continue throughout 2008.

Last point the SG&A, as regards to SG&A, Chris Mulliez exclaimed that their weight was stable, including the impact in integration of American distributors and excluding the increase of the IFRS chart on the stock option. Let's not forget that there are currency fluctuations that negatively impact our business in this area because all of our central costs are in euros. We're working more than ever to accelerate our policy for permanent restructuring to optimize our organizations and streamline our cost.

Just a few examples, we are currently completing, grouping together, all of our subsidiaries in the European countries in common headquarters so as to optimize back office operations. We transferred, at the beginning of this year, to the Directorate for Industrial Purchases, the responsibility for purchasing all of our indirect purchases and this will help get tremendous savings.

We're also putting resources, we want to adopt to the evolution of distribution in retail and reduce our costs. As you can see, we have stepped up our efforts in these areas and this will produce a number of results and we think that we still have a number of avenues for improvement.
